tooltips.audioFile: Choose an audio file from your computer (MP3, WAV, M4A, etc.). This is the recording you want to convert to text.
tooltips.method: Pick how your audio gets converted to text. Azure AI Speech is best for multi-speaker meetings. Azure Whisper is great for general-purpose transcription.
tooltips.languageCandidates: If your meeting has people speaking multiple languages, list the possible language codes here (e.g. en-US,nl-NL). The system will detect which language is being spoken in each part.
tooltips.profanityFilter: Choose how swear words are handled: Masked replaces them with ****, Removed deletes them entirely, Raw keeps them as-is.
tooltips.maxSpeakers: Set the maximum number of distinct speakers you expect in the recording. A higher number won't hurt accuracy but helps the system prepare for larger meetings.
tooltips.wordLevelTimestamps: When enabled, each individual word gets its own timestamp ‚Äî useful if you need precise timing for captions or subtitles.
tooltips.temperature: Controls randomness in the transcription. Keep it at 0 for the most accurate results. Higher values may produce varied but less reliable output.
tooltips.initialPrompt: Give the AI context about your audio ‚Äî names of people, technical terms, or the topic being discussed. This helps it transcribe unfamiliar words correctly.
tooltips.language: Specify the language spoken in the recording (e.g. en-US for American English). Leave empty to let the system detect it automatically.
tooltips.customTerms: List specialised words, acronyms, or names that the AI might not recognise ‚Äî like product names, project codes, or technical jargon. One per line or comma-separated.
tooltips.termsFile: Instead of typing custom terms one by one, upload a text file (.txt or .csv) containing your vocabulary list ‚Äî one term per line.
tooltips.enableDiarization: Speaker diarization figures out "who said what" in your recording. It labels each part of the conversation with a speaker name. Essential for meetings with multiple participants.
tooltips.enableNlp: Turns on smart text analysis after transcription. This extracts a summary, key phrases, sentiment (positive/negative tone), named entities, and action items from your meeting.
tooltips.summaryLength: Controls how long the auto-generated summary will be. A higher number of sentences means a more detailed summary; lower means a brief overview.
tooltips.nlpSegmentSentiment: Analyses the emotional tone of each individual speech segment, so you can see how sentiment changed throughout the meeting.
tooltips.sentimentThreshold: Minimum confidence score required to label a segment as positive or negative. Segments below this threshold are marked as neutral. Higher values mean only strong sentiments are shown; lower values make detection more sensitive.
tooltips.nlpKeyPhrases: Automatically extracts the most important words and phrases from the transcription ‚Äî great for a quick overview of what was discussed.
tooltips.nlpEntities: Finds and labels people, organisations, locations, dates, and other named things mentioned in the meeting.
tooltips.nlpActionItems: Detects commitments and to-dos mentioned during the meeting, like "John will send the report by Friday".
tooltips.nlpSummary: Generates a concise summary of the entire meeting, capturing the main points discussed.
tooltips.audioChannels: Number of audio channels. Use 1 (mono) for best speech recognition results. Use 2 (stereo) only if your recording has separate speaker channels.
tooltips.audioSampleRate: Audio sample rate in Hz. 16 kHz is optimal for speech recognition. Higher rates preserve more audio detail but increase processing time and file size.
tooltips.audioBitRate: Audio encoding bit rate. Lower values reduce file size, higher values preserve quality. 16k is sufficient for speech; use higher for music or high-fidelity recordings.
